summary: This bill proposes to award a Congressional Gold Medal, collectively, to Africans and their descendants enslaved in the United States from August 20, 1619, to December 6, 1865. The medal aims to recognize their contributions to the foundation of America's economic greatness. The bill outlines findings about the history of slavery, including its economic impact and the suffering it caused. It directs the Speaker of the House and President pro tempore of the Senate to arrange for the medal, which will be displayed at the Smithsonian's National Museum of African American History and Culture. The Secretary of the Treasury is authorized to strike and sell bronze duplicates, with proceeds going to the United States Mint Public Enterprise Fund.
